description.value: The Vienna Normal School was reopened on 1 May 1775 in the St. Anna building in Johannesgasse (1010 Vienna) under the directorate of Josef Messmer (1731-1804). It was a model school for the training of teachers. One of the experts in this school was Johann Ignaz Melchior von Felbiger (1724-1788). He was subordinate to the Studienhofkommission (Ministry of Education), but he lectured and taught in Vienna, wrote textbooks for the new schools (first Austrian reading book, various editions of the Catechism, computational and language books as well as related methodical instructions). Three reformers of the school system for the Serbs in the Habsburg Empire, namely Stefan Vujanovski (1743-1829), Teodor Janković Mirijevski (1741-1814) and Avram Mrazović (1756-1826) completed Felbiger's course. The Academy of Fine Arts was also moved here in 1786. Many Serbian students studied in this Academy, among them Dimitrije Avramović (1836-1840).

Three reformers of school system for Serbs in Habsburg Empire, Stefan Vujanovski, Teodor Janković Mirijevski and Avram Mrazović completed Felbiger’s course.

description.value: Jovan Barbulović was the owner of a factory for French ties. He received a privilege for this kind of trade on 27 October 1845. Therefore, he founded his company entitled "Barbulowits Joh. D" for textiles and men's wear in 1846. Its address at that time was in Vienna's city centre, namely house No. 589 (that is Bauernmarkt 2a, 1010 Vienna, does not exist anymore). Jovan Barbulović was exporting his products even to Italy and the Orient.

description.value: This was the last apartment of King Milan Obrenović (1854-1901) from 4 December 1900 to 11 February 1901, when he died. The apartment was on the first floor. It is not clear what happened with King Milan's legacy. After his death all objects from the apartment were transferred to Belgrade, but after the overthrow of the Obrenović Dynasty in 1903 its destiny is unknown. One of the possible answers could be the two auctions in the Viennese auction house "Dorotheum" from 1905 and 1906. On the first auction (10-16 October 1905) Queen Natalija Obrenović (1859-1941), Milan's former wife, sold objects of the Kings Milan and Aleksandar. It was a collection of 1166 objects (silverware, porcelain, ivory, bronze, vases, statues, lamps, paintings and furniture from the Royal Palace in Belgrade). The second auction took place on 30 October 1906. Here were offered 126 objects, among them 110 paintings.

description.value: Jakim Piniuk wurde 1877 in Berbicznej im historischen Bezirk Waszkoutz geboren. Berbicznej könnte die Ortschaft Brusnytsia (vormals Berbestie) oder ein Ort in der Gegend um Berezhnytsia und Berezhonka (vormals Bereznica und Beretnica) sein. Der Bezirk Waszkoutz (heute Vashkivtsi) befand sich in der historischen Landschaft Bukowina in Österreich-Ungarn und liegt heute in der Ukraine.------------ Jakim Piniuk was born in Berbicznej in the historical district of Waszkoutz in 1877.  Berbicznej could be the village of Brusnytsia (formerly Berbestie) or a place in the region around Berezhnytsia and Berezhonka (formerly Bereznica and Beretnica). The district of Waszkoutz (today Vashkivtsi) was in the historical region of Bucovina in Austria-Hungary and is located in Ukraine today.

description.value: Ilie Czuczuliak und Maria Mokowey wurden 1840 und 1915 in Breaza im ehemaligen Bezirk Kimpolung geboren. Im Bezirk Kimpolung befanden sich zwei Orte namens Breaza. Der größere, auch Briaza genannt, existiert heute noch. Der kleinere ist Teil des Ortes Ciocănești. Beide befanden sich in der historischen Landschaft Bukowina in Österreich-Ungarn und gehören heute zu Rumänien.  ------------ Ilie Czuczuliak and Maria Mokowey were born in Breaza in the former district of Kimpolung in 1840 and 1915. There were two villages called Breaza in the district of Kimpolung. The larger one, also called Briaza, still exists. The smaller one is now part of the village of  Ciocănești. Both were in the historical region of Bucovina in Austria-Hungary and are located in Romania today.

properties.title: Chapel of the Russian Legation in Vienna

description.value:
From 1820 to 1906 this building was the property of the Russian Empire. Apart from the Russian Legation there was also a Russian Orthodox chapel in the same building, in which the Russian Orthodox priest Mihail Fjodorovič Rajevski (1811-1884) was serving. 
In this chapel Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) married Countess Julie Hunyady de Kéthely (1831-1919) on 1 August 1853. On the feast of St. Sava (27 January) in 1859 Kornelije Stanković (1831-1865) performed his "Liturgy" in the same chapel.

Apart from Croatian there were many Serbian officials, among them for example Dimitrije Musulin (1833-1865), Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski (1817-1890), Mihajlo Polit Desančić (1833-1920) etc.

Here died the Viennese merchant Nikola Krestić on 18 October 1856.

description.value: “Mlada Srbadija” was a short-time published journal from January 1876. The owner and editor was Nikola Kapamadžija. The first issue from 1 January 1876 had a picture of Svetozar Miletić, the political leader of the Serbs in Vojvodina. The content was rich and manifold: texts from Jovan Stefanović Vilovski and Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša, poems and biographies. The journal was planned to be published three times a month and printed in the Mechitarist Monastery printing house. Only three issues were published, all of them in January 1876.The address of the editorial office was Ottakringer Hauptstrasse 9, but the building does not exists anymore.

description.value: “Nemanja” was an illustrated journal for entertainment and education between 1887 and 1888. The owner and editor was Konstantin Mandrović (1840-1920). The first issue was published in July 1887, and the address of the editorial office was: Hauptstraße 22 (Landstraßer Hauptstraße 22, the building still exists ). The editors were also Simeun Konjević, Branko Anović and Franja Jonak. "Nemanja" was printed in the publishing house of N. Vernaj in Vienna. It had 11 issues in total: 6 in 1887 and 5 in 1888 (until May).

properties.title: Editorial office of Serbskija Povsednevnija Novini

description.value: The first Serbian daily newspapers “Serbskija Povsednevnija novini” were printed in Vienna by the Greek brothers Poulios Markidis-Pouliou and Georgios Markidis-Pouliou from 1791 until 1792. The first issue was published on 14 March 1791. The newspaper was published twice a week until 10 December 1792, in total 183 numbers. From issue 15 onwards the newspaper was renamed into “Serbskija novini”.It was printed in the printing house of Josef von Kurzböck in Church-Slavonic language.

description.value: "Srbadija" was an illustrated journal, which was printed on a monthly basis in the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation from 26 October 1874 (first issue) until 1 March 1877 (last issue). It had 18 issues in total. The editorial office was in Ungargasse 2 (1030 Vienna; the building does not exist anymore). The first owner and publisher of "Srbadija" was Todor Stefanović Vilovski (1854-1921), its editor Srećko Majer. Starting with issue No. 2 the owner and publisher was Stevan Ćurčić, the editor Srećko Majer. Since 1876 (issue No. 5) the owner and publisher was Stevan Ćurčić, the editor Franja Ptačovski, and the journal was printed in the Bulgarian printing house of Janko Kovačev. The last issue of 1877 was coordinated by the owner, publisher and editor Jovan F. Lulej.

description.value: "Srpska Zora" was a Serbian illustrated journal, which was published monthly from 1876 to 1881, having a total of 44 issues. The first issue was edited on 1 January 1876. The owner and publisher was Konstantin Kosta Mandrović (1840-1920), the editor Mita Georgiević. The address of the editorial office was in the beginning Pragerstraße 13 (1030 Vienna) and, starting with the third issue, Gärtnergasse 24 (1030 Vienna). The owner of "Srpska zora", starting with the fourth issue, was Todor Stefanović Vilovski (1854-1921), and the publisher Konstantin Kosta Mandrović. With Issue No. 6 the address of the editorial office was was Burggasse 24 (1070). "Srpska Zora" had a patriotic content, which becomes evident through the war illustrations of the Ottoman-Serbian wars 1876-1878. Apart from that poems and novels of the most famous Serbian authors were published in this journal, like those of Djura Jakšić, Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša, Jakov Ignjatović, Milorad Šapčanin, Jovan Jovanović Zmaj, Prince Nikola Petrović of Montenegro, Laza Kostić, Laza Lazarević and many others. In 1877 the journal had 1,000 subscribers, and since 1878 novels of European authors like Turgenjev, Keller, Sacher-Masoch etc. were published in translation in every issue. The journal was printed in the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation and later in the printing house of Janko Kovačev.

description.value: “Svetovid” was an illustrated journal, which was published in Vienna by Alekandar Andrić from 3 June 1853 to 1859. Until 30 December 1856 341 issues were printed in total. “Svetovid” was printed in the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation in Vienna  until 1856 and then in Andrić's publishing house. In 1853 the journal had 366 subscribers, in 1855 500, in 1856 700 and in 1858 408. The first address of the editorial office was Lerchenfelderstraße 22 (1080 Vienna), then since 24 June 1853 Lerchenfelderstraße 27 (1080 Vienna). Since 2 June 1854 it was to be found in Mohrengasse 756 in Leopoldstadt (Große Mohrengasse 27, 1020 Vienna). The last address of the editorial office since 26 April 1856 was in neue Schottengasse 113 (Piaristengasse 26, 1080 Vienna).

description.value: Nikola Jovanović was a furrier, who founded his company in Vienna in 1901, which still exists. Since its foundation until the end of the Second World War (1945) the shop was located in Piaristengasse 7 (1080 Vienna). The building does not exist anymore. Among more than one hundred shops of Serbian merchants in Vienna in the 19th and at the beginning of 20th centuries, the only one, which exists nowadays, is the Jovanović furrier shop. It is located since the 1940s in Weihburggasse 3 and 9 (1010 Vienna) and is run by Jovanović's granddaughter.

description.value: The third Slavic Ball took place in the Graziensäle ("Zur goldenen Birne") on 2 February 1846. Among the guests were more than twenty Austrian Counts and Barons (the Prince Schwarzenberg, Thun, Kinsky, etc.). On this occasion Johann Strauss Junior ("Son", 1825-1899) performed his composition op. 14 "Serben Quadrille" for the first time. The composition was dedicated to Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) and was printed in Vienna in 4,000 pieces. The Graziensäle were demolished in 1876.

On this occasion Johann Strauss Son played his composition op. 14 “Serben Quadrille”for the first time. The composition was dedicated to Prince Mihailo and was printed in Vienna in 4,000 pieces. The building was demolished in 1876.

properties.title: Greek Catholic Church of St. Barbara

description.value: Today the Greek Catholic Church of St. Barbara is the Ukrainian Greek Catholic central parish in Vienna. The building was erected from 1652 to 1654 as a seminary of the Jesuit order. After the suppression of the Jesuit order in 1773 by the Emperor Joseph II (1741-1790) and the closure of the seminary, Empress Maria Theresia (1717-1780) donated the seminary together with its church to the Greek Catholic Church in October 1775. In 1784 the seminary was abolished and a parish was installed.

properties.title: Greek Orthodox Church of Saint George

description.value: The Greek Orthodox Confraternity of St. George (Ἑλληνικὴ Κοινότης Ἁγίου Γεωργίου) was most probably founded by the Greeks with Ottoman citizenship after the second Ottoman siege of Vienna in 1683. The Confraternity obtained, with the support of the famous Austrian General Prince Eugene of Savoy (1663-1736), an imperial privilege by the Emperor Karl VI of Habsburg (1685-1740) in 1723, which allowed the foundation of the first Orthodox chapel in Vienna. It was dedicated to St. George and was first located in the Dempfingerhof (Seitenstettengasse 4, 1010 Vienna) and then in the Steyrerhof (Griechengasse 3, 1010 Vienna). The Confraternity received imperial privileges by the Empress Maria Theresia (1717-1780) and the Emperors Joseph II (1741-1790), Leopold II (1747-1792) and Franz II (1768-1835). In 1803 Georg Johann Ritter von Karajan (1743-1813), a Greek with Austrian citizenship, bought two houses (No. 758 "zum kleinen Küßdenpfennig Haus" and No. 757 "Wagner-" or "Binder-Häuschen") in the Griechengasse and ceded both to the Confraternity. In the same year the headstone for a Church of St. George was laid and it was built by the architect Franz Wipplinger (1760-1812) until 1806 at a cost of 126,784 florins. It was renovated through the generosity of the Greek banker and industrialist Nikolaos Dumba (1830-1900) in the year 1898. A belfry was erected by the architect Ludwig Tischler (1840-1906). After more than 100 years His Eminence Metropolitan Arsenios of Austria accomplished an extensive renovation of the church in the years 2015/2016. The Greek Orthodox Church of St. George is the oldest Orthodox church on the territory of the Republic of Austria. In the past and the present many generations of Orthodox Christians joined in this church for prayer. Jekatarina-Katica Obrenović (1826-1848), the daughter of Prince Miloš's youngest brother Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), died in Vienna on 25 July 1848 and, after a memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George, was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). In 1885 a memorial service was held for the Serbian Prince Aleksandar Karadjordjević (1806-1885) by Bishop Djordje Branković and 17 other clergymen in this very church.

properties.title: Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity

description.value:
The Greek Orthodox Confraternity of the Holy Trinity (Ἑλληνικὴ Κοινότης  Ἁγίας Τριάδος) was founded by the Greeks with Austrian citizenship in 1787. The Confraternity bought a house in Fleischmarkt 13 (1010 Vienna), which was transformed into a church by the architect Peter Mollner (1732-1801). The Confraternity received imperial privileges by the Habsburg emperors Joseph II (1741-1790) in 1787 and by Franz II (1768-1835) in 1796. The renovation of the Church of the Holy Trinity took place in 1833 and from 1856 to 1858. The renovation in the 1850s was mostly financed by Baron Simon von Sina (1810-1876), who donated an amount of 70,000 florins. The renowned architect Theophil von Hansen (1813-1891) created a facade and church spire in Neo-Byzantine-style, which the Viennese population called "Das goldene Haus" ("The Golden House"). The church's last renovation was undertaken from 1989 to 1993.
Jovan Subotić (1817-1886) and Jelisaveta Savka Subotić (1834-1918) married in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity on 1 May 1851. At the wedding were present Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) with his family, Djordje Stojaković (1810-1863), Kornelije Stanković (1831-1865), the Russian Orthodox priest Mihail Fjodorovič Rajevski (1811-1884) and Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868). Their best men were the lawyer and official Pavle Trifunac (1796-1882) and the Viennese merchant Jovan Vladislav.
On 10 May 1854 Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) was best man at the wedding of Major General Djordje Stratimirović (1822-1908) in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity. 
Cezar Popović (1876-1938), a Viennese architect and artist, was baptised in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt (1010 Vienna) on 21 March 1876. In 1890 a memorial service was celebrated in the church for the Austrian General and nobleman Gavrilo Rodić (1812-1890).

description.value: In the vicinity of the funerary monument of the Austrian general Ernst Gideon Freiherr von Laudon (1717-1790) in today's 14th Viennese district, which was built in neoclassical style in 1791, are to be found the so-called "Türkensteine". After the conquest of Ottoman Belgrade by the Austrian general Laudon on 8 October 1789 he ordered that parts of Ottoman stone sculptures from the fortress of Belgrade (called "Kalemegdan") were to be brought to Vienna as symbol of victory. They comprise two marble plaques, which were put on the Stambul Gate of the fortress of Belgrade under the Ottoman Sultan Mahmud I (1696-1754), and four smaller plaques of marble deriving from the tomb of the former commander of the fortress, Ibrahim Pasha, who died in 1708. These stone sculptures are still to be found in the forest of Laudon's former estate in Hadersdorf, to the North of Schloß Laudon alongside the Mauerbachstraße.

properties.title: House of Danilo Žefarović in Fleischmarkt 16

description.value:
Danilo Žefarović built the house called "zur weißen Rose" in Fleischmarkt 16 (1010 Vienna) at the beginning of the 19th century (ca. 1800) and died there on 3 May 1806. On the facade, among other ornamental reliefs, there is to be seen the coat of arms of the family Žefarović above the gate. 
Many Serbian merchants lived or had their stores in Fleischmarkt during the 19th century.

Here was the seat of the Company "Gebrüder Stova", which was owned by the brothers Aleksandar Stova (1836-1898) and Mihajlo Stova (1834-1879). The company existed from 1864 until 1898. 

The Company "Mirovich D.C." also had its seat at this place since the year 1847. Its owner was Dimitrije Konstantin Mirović, a merchant, treasurer of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna and one of the initiators of the founding of this very community in 1860. 

Here died the Serbian merchant Vasilije Aleksić (1813-1877) at the age of 64 on 7 March 1877 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).

In their neighborhood was Arthur Schnitzler (1862-1931), who wrote in his autobiography about the childhood of the young Milan. Milan's mother Marija was the owner of the house in Hirschengasse 29 (today Billrothstraße 29, 1190 Vienna). This house does not exist anymore.

description.value: Nikola Kapamadžija, a merchant, newspaper editor, commercial school director and President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Comunity Council of St. Sava in Vienna from 1897, was the owner of the house in Millergasse 43 (1060 Vienna; does not exist anymore) together with his wife Marie. They bought this house in 1900. In the same year they purchased the house in Bürgerspitalgasse 30 (1060 Vienna). In this building he founded a commercial school ("Handelsschule"), with himself as director. Apart from the school there was also a dorm for the students. The building does not exist anymore.

properties.title: House of Prince Miloš Obrenović in Untere Donaustraße

description.value:
Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) bought this house at the latest in 1852 and used it for renting. In the year 1855 he gave this house over to his friend and banker Demeter Theodor Tirka (ca. 1802–1874) in exchange for a house in Salesianergasse 11 (1030 Vienna). The latter was a gift to his son Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) and his wife Princess Julie Hunyady de Kéthely (1831-1919). The building in Untere Donaustraße 23 does not exist anymore.

In this house lived Velimir Barbarić (1823-1902), secretary of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna and one of the initiators of the founding of this community in 1860.

description.value: In August 1745 Empress Maria Theresia (1717-1780) founded the so-called "Illyrische Hofkommission" for the Serbian population of her realm and its administration. On 5 August 1747 it was renamed in "Illyrische Hofdeputation" and put under the direct control of the Habsburg ruler. The  "Illyrische Hofdeputation" issued two Regulamenta in 1770 and 1777 and was finally dissolved in 1792.

description.value: Johann Schnierer was a Viennese printer from 1813 to 1818. Amongst others, he printed many Serbian books,for example Vuk Karadzić´s first books in Vienna in 1814, called “Pjesmarica” (Mala prostonarodna slaveno-serbska pjesmarica) and “Pismenica”. His printing house was on in Landstrasse 248. Today it is the address Landstraßer Hauptstraße 92, but the building does not exist anymore.

properties.title: Konstantinović de German house in Grashofgasse

description.value: Stefan Konstantinović de German bought this house on 5 April 1814. After his death his sucessors were Dimitrije, Konstantin, Helene, Anna, Alexandra, Johann, Eugen and Isidor Konstantinović de German.  From 1856 Dimitrije was the only owner and sold the house to Michael Sterio Dumba (1828-1894) in 1863. The building does not exist anymore.

description.value: Dieser digitale Lehrpfad durch das ehemalige Flüchtlingslager Oberhollabrunn (jetzt Gartenstadt in Hollabrunn) ermöglicht BesucherInnen die interaktive Erschließung noch existierender bzw. sichtbarer Infrastruktur aus der Zeit des Ersten Weltkriegs. Der GPS basierte Spaziergang dauert rund 50 Minuten. Zu jedem Gebäude bzw. historischen Ort entlang des Lehrpfads können gezielt gesonderte Informationen und Photographien abgerufen werden. ------------ This digital trail through the former refugee camp Oberhollabrunn (now the so-called Gartenstadt in Hollabrunn) enables the visitors to approach interactively the still existing and visible infrastructure from the times of the First World War. The GPS-based trail takes ca. 50 minutes. The visitors can read additional data on each building or historic site along the trail and access respective photographs.

description.value: Nikola Jovanović was a fur merchant who founded his company in Vienna in 1901, which still exists today. Since the foundation until the end of the Second World War the shop was located in Piaristengasse 7. From more than hundred shops of Serbian merchants in Vienna in the 19th and at the beginning of 20th century, the only one which still exist today is the Jovanović fur house located since the 1940s in Weihburggasse 3 and 9 and which is run by Jovanović´s granddaughter.

description.value:
Die Bänke des Dr. Viktor Zeidler Platzes laden zu einer kurzen Verweilpause und einer Betrachtung des Lagerplanes ein.

Zu Beginn der Flüchtlingsströme 1914 wurden in den Lagern ausschließlich riesige Holzbaracken errichtet. Diese waren kostengünstig, schnell herstellbar und konnten vielfältig verwendet werden, etwa als Schlafsäle, Küchen, Schulen oder Spitäler. Bis zu 500 Personen wurden in einer Baracke untergebracht.

Im Verlauf des Krieges ging man zu immer kleineren Unterkünften über, da sich in den Massenquartieren rasant Krankheiten ausbreiteten. Zu den schlecht haltbaren Holzbaracken, in die Kälte und Feuchtigkeit eindrangen, kamen nun auch kleinere gemauerte Wohngebäude und die Lager wurden zusehends mit einer modernen Infrastruktur ausgestattet.

Bei der Planung des Lagers Oberhollabrunn, das erst in einer fortgeschrittenen Phase des Krieges entstand, wurde auf eine Weiterverwendungsmöglichkeit nach dem Krieg Rücksicht genommen. Aus diesem Grund entstanden hier auch zahlreiche gemauerte Gebäude. Seitens der Gemeinde gab es den Wunsch, die Gebäude zukünftig als Kriegerheimstätten für invalide Soldaten zu nutzen.

Im Jänner 1916 wurden die Äcker zwischen Oberhollabrunn und Raschala angekauft und in den darauffolgenden Monaten entstand eine autarke Siedlung mit über 100 Bauobjekten. Die Infrastruktur umfasste neben Wohnhäusern und -baracken auch zahlreiche Verwaltungs- und Wirtschaftsgebäude. Das Lager wurde an die städtische Wasserversorgung und das Elektrizitätsnetz angeschlossen und eine Schmalspurbahn brachte Material und Waren vom Bahnhof Hollabrunn.
------------
The benches on the Dr. Viktor Zeidler Platz invite us to rest for a moment and take a look at the plan of the refugee camp.

At the beginning of the flow of refugees in 1914 huge wooden barracks were erected in the camps. These barracks were cheap, quickly producible and could be used in manifold ways, for example as dormitories, kitchens, schools or hospitals. Up to 500 people were accommodated per barrack.

In the course of the war smaller housing was constructed, because diseases were spreading rapidly in mass accommodation. Apart from the poorly durable wooden barracks, which were exposed to the cold and humidity, smaller masoned residential buildings were erected, and the camps were furnished with modern infrastructure.

In the planning of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn, which was built in an advanced phase of the war, the possibility of a reuse after the war was taken into account. That is why many masoned buildings were constructed. On the part of the municipality the wish existed to use the buildings as asylum for invalid soldiers in the future.

In January 1916 the fields between Oberhollabrunn and Raschala were acquired and in the following months a self-sufficient settlement with more than 100 objects was constructed. Apart from residential buildings and barracks the infrastructure comprised many administrative and commercial buildings. The camp was connected to the municipal water and power supply and a narrow-gauge railway brought material and goods from the railway station Hollabrunn.

description.value:
Auf der rechten Straßenseite befanden sich Wohnbaracken für Angestellte des Lagers.
Eine der Baracken ist heute noch erhalten (der hintere Teil des Hauses Dr. Kutschergasse 5). Der vordere Gebäudeteil wurde im Jahr 1935 errichtet.
------------
On the right-hand side of the street were located residential barracks for the camp's employees. One of the barracks is still preserved (i.e. the rear part of the house Dr. Kutschergasse 5). The front part of the building was erected in the year 1935.

description.value:
Im Frühjahr 1918 wurden die Flüchtlinge vom Bahnhof Hollabrunn zurück in ihre teilweise zerstörte Heimat transportiert. Die leerstehenden Gebäude dienten ab August 1918 der Erholungsfürsorge für Wiener Kinder und Jugendliche. Lehrmädchen und -buben erhielten hier die Möglichkeit, einen vierwöchigen Kuraufenthalt zu verbringen.

An dieser Stelle (Übelbachergasse 25-27) befand sich eine gemauerte Baracke. Auf der Aufnahme sind die hier einquartierten Kinder beim Reinigen ihrer Kleidung vor der Baracke zu sehen.

Die Erholungsfürsorge wurde im anschließenden Winter in eine Erziehungsanstalt für verwahrloste Jugendliche umgewandelt, die bis 1921 mit Unterstützung der Gemeinde Wien betrieben wurde.
------------
In the spring of 1918 the refugees were transported from the railway station Hollabrunn back to their partly destroyed homeland. The abandoned buildings were used to accommodate Viennese children and youths from August 1918 to enable their recreation. Apprentices had the opportunity to spend four weeks on holidays, in an environment similar to a health resort.

At this place (Übelbachergasse 25-27) was located a masoned barrack. On the recording we can see the accommodated children, who clean their clothes in front of the barrack.

In the winter of 1918 the camp was again transformed from a center for recreation to a reformatory for neglected youths, which was sustained by the municipality of Vienna until 1921.

description.value:
Auf dem Grundstück Schirnböckgasse 9 befand sich die Wache der Lagerfeuerwehr. Sie verfügte über eigene Löschfahrzeuge, die auf den Aufnahmen aus dem Jahr 1918 zu sehen sind.

Das später in ein Wohnhaus umgebaute Gebäude wurde mittlerweile abgerissen.

 ------------ 

On the site of the Schirnböckgasse 9 was the camp's fire station. The fire brigade had its own firefighting vehicles, which can be seen on the recording of the year 1918.

The fire station was later transformed into a residential building and has been pulled down in the meantime.

description.value:
Auf einer Postkarte aus dem Jahr 1917, die der Bauleiter des Lagers, Ing. Gröger, an einen Kollegen in Wien schrieb, befindet sich eine Aufnahme, die an dieser Stelle, mit Blick Richtung Norden, gemacht wurde. Die Flüchtlinge versammeln sich auf der Straße vor ihren Häusern. Im Hintergrund sind mehrere Holzbaracken, zwei gemauerte Baracken und ein Einfamilienhaus zu sehen.
------------
On a postcard from 1917, which the camp's site manager, engineer Gröger, wrote to a colleague in Vienna, shows a picture, which was made at this spot towards the North. The refugees assembled on the street in front of their houses. In the background several wooden barracks, two masoned barracks and a single family house can be discerned.

description.value:
Neben der römisch-katholischen Kirche "Maria, Hilfe der Christen" wurde im Jahr 2000 eine Gedenktafel in Erinnerung an die hier internierten Italiener errichtet.

Auch von der südlichen Front wurden viele Tausende geflüchtete und evakuierte Menschen ins Innere der Monarchie transportiert, so etwa aus dem zu Österreich-Ungarn gehörenden Trentino. Die italienischsprachigen Flüchtlinge wurden vorrangig in den Lagern in Mitterndorf an der Fischa, Bruck an der Leitha und Wagna bei Leibnitz untergebracht. Eine Minderheit war auch in Oberhollabrunn einquartiert.

Rund einen Kilometer vom Lager entfernt, beim Alten Forsthaus zu Raschala, befand sich außerdem eine Internierungsstation für "Feindstaatenausländer" (d. h. in der Monarchie wohnhafte Bürger*innen anderer Staaten). Hier wurden vor allem Italiener "konfiniert".

 ------------ 

In the vicinity of the Roman Catholic Church "Maria, Hilfe der Christen" ("Mary, Aid of the Christians") a commemorative plaque in remembrance of the interned Italians was placed in the year 2000. 

Thousands of fled and evacuated people along the Southern front were also transported to the inner parts of the Austro-Hungarian monarchy, for example from Austrian ruled Trentino. The Italian speaking refugees were mainly brought to the camps in Mitterndorf an der Fischa, Bruck an der Leitha and Wagna near Leibnitz. A minority was also accommodated in Oberhollabrunn.

About 1 km from the camp, near the Old Forester's House in Raschala, a detention camp for the so-called "Feindstaatenausländer" (i.e. citizens from other states living in the Austro-Hungarian monarchy) was to be found. It was here that especially Italians were "confined".

properties.title: Oberhollabrunn, Flüchtlingslager, Gedenktafel für Josef Waditschatka

description.value:
Auf ein weiteres bedeutendes Ereignis für die Stadt Hollabrunn verweist die Gedenktafel für den Postbeamten und Sozialdemokraten Josef Waditschatka an der Übelbachergasse 23, der sein Zuhause in einem ehemaligen Lager-Einfamilienhaus fand und am 8. Mai 1945 mit der Roten Armee die friedliche Übergabe der Stadt aushandelte.

Unsere Erzählung über das Flüchtlingslager Oberhollabrunn endet an dieser Stelle. Durch die Weitläufigkeit des ehemaligen Lagerareals konnten nicht alle erhaltenen Gebäude in unserer Tour berücksichtigt werden. Die übrigen befinden sich an folgenden Adressen: 
Emmy Stradal Straße 49, Emmy Stradal Straße 55, Gilleisstraße 97, Luschangasse 16, Luschangasse 23 (Einfamilienhäuser), Schirnböckgasse 15 (Zweifamilienhaus), Gilleisstraße 35, Gilleisstraße 46 und Gilleisstraße 51 (umgebaute Baracken).
Ein sowjetischer Soldatenfriedhof aus dem Zweiten Weltkrieg an der Ecke Jahnstraße/Schützengasse und der Friedhof der Stadt Hollabrunn, auf dem die Flüchtlinge im Ersten Weltkrieg begraben wurden, wovon jedoch heute jede Spur fehlt, laden zu einem Besuch ein.

Wir danken dem Zukunftsfonds der Republik Österreich für die finanzielle Projektförderung, der griechisch-orthodoxen Metropolis von Austria für die infrastrukturelle und wissenschaftliche Unterstützung, dem Austrian Institute of Technology (AIT) für die technische Zusammenarbeit und dem Stadtarchiv Hollabrunn für die archivische Beratung.

------------ 

On the corner of Übelbachergasse 23 a commemorative plaque in honor of the post office clerk and social democrat Josef Waditschatka hints to an important event in the history of Hollabrunn. Waditschatka lived in this former single family house of the refugee camp and negotiated the peaceful surrender of Hollabrunn to the Red Army on 8 May 1945.   

Our story of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn ends at this point. Because of the extent of the former camp not all preserved buildings were included in our tour. The remaining buildings can be found at the following addresses: 
Emmy Stradal Straße 49, Emmy Stradal Straße 55, Gilleisstraße 97, Luschangasse 16, Luschangasse 23 (single family houses), Schirnböckgasse 15 (semi-detached house), Gilleisstraße 35, Gilleisstraße 46 und Gilleisstraße 51 (rebuilt barracks).
A Soviet military cemetery from the Second World War on the corner Jahnstraße/Schützengasse can be visited as well as the cemetery of Hollabrunn, where the refugees were buried in the First World War, but of which no trace remains.

We are grateful to the Future Fund of the Republic of Austria for the funding of the project, the Greek-Orthodox Metropolis of Austria for the infrastructural and scholarly support, the Austrian Institute of Technology (AIT) for the technical cooperation and the Municipal Archive Hollabrunn for the archival assistance.

description.value:
Das Haus Schirnböckgasse 7 ist ein sogenanntes "gemauertes Einfamilienhaus Type 11", das im Lager Oberhollabrunn insgesamt zehnmal errichtet wurde. Es wurde seitlich erweitert und weicht vom ursprünglichen Grundriss, den alle Einfamilienhäuser gemeinsam haben, ab.

 ------------ 

The house in the Schirnböckgasse 7 is a so-called "gemauertes Einfamilienhaus Type 11", which was erected altogether ten times in the camp Oberhollabrunn. It was enlarged on the side and, thus, differs from the original room layout, which otherwise all single family houses have in common.

description.value:
Die Gemeinde Oberhollabrunn wollte nach der Rückkehr der Flüchtlinge in ihre Heimat das Lager als Stadterweiterungsgebiet übernehmen. Eine Einigung mit dem Bund, der im Besitz der Bauobjekte war, konnte aber erst 1922 erzielt werden. Das Lagerareal wurde schließlich zwischen Bund und Gemeinde aufgeteilt und die einzelnen Gründe und Objekte verkauft oder verpachtet. Die Holzbaracken wurden demoliert und die gemauerten Gebäude entsprechend adaptiert oder erweitert. So entstand der neue Ortsteil Gartenstadt.

Nach dem Zweiten Weltkrieg folgte schließlich eine weitere Bau-Offensive. Die freien Grundstücke zwischen den Objekten wurden nun bebaut und ein eigener Siedlerverein zu diesem Zweck gegründet.

 ------------ 

After the return of the refugees to their homeland the municipality of Oberhollabrunn wanted to take over the camp for its urban expansion. An agreement with the central administration in Vienna, which was the owner of the edifices, could only be reached in 1922. The area of the camp was finally divided between the central administration and the municipality, and the individual plots of land and buildings were either sold or leased. The wooden barracks were demolished and the masoned buildings were adapted or enlarged. In this way a new urban area called "Gartenstadt" came into being.

After the Second World War another phase of construction activity took place. The empty plots of land between the edifices were built on, and even a building association was founded for this purpose.

description.value:
In umgestalteter Form ist uns ein Teil des Flüchtlingslagers bis heute erhalten geblieben und dient als Erinnerungsort für Ereignisse des Ersten Weltkriegs, die nahezu in Vergessenheit geraten sind. Das räumliche Ausmaß, das die Unterbringung der zahlreichen Flüchtlinge und Evakuierten annahm, wird bei der Betrachtung der heutigen Gartenstadt erahnbar. Und dennoch war das hiesige Lager nur eines unter vielen, die sich über das gesamte Gebiet der k. u. k. Monarchie erstreckten. 

Wenngleich das Flüchtlingslager in dieser Funktion nur über einen kurzen Zeitabschnitt von zwei Jahren bestand, so war es Teil einer langfristigen historischen Entwicklung. Barackenlager für Kriegsgefangene hatten sich bereits seit dem 19. Jahrhundert etabliert. Um 1900 entstanden die ersten als Konzentrationslager bezeichneten Internierungsstationen für Zivilisten, etwa im Spanisch-Amerikanischen Krieg auf Kuba (1898) oder im Zuge des sogenannten Zweiten Burenkriegs in Südafrika (1899-1902).

Größere Dimensionen und neue Formen der Architektur nahmen die Lager aller kriegsführenden Staaten im Ersten Weltkrieg an. Besonders die k. u. k. Monarchie errichtete ein umfassendes System von Lagern für Kriegsgefangene, "Feindstaatenausländer", Evakuierte und Flüchtlinge, die als "Sammelniederlassungen", "Barackenstädte", "Internierungsstationen" oder "Konzentrationslager" bezeichnet wurden. Sie dienten der Versorgung Heimatloser, genauso aber der Steuerung und Isolation von Menschenmassen.

Ein grausamer Höhepunkt wurde mit den NS-Vernichtungslagern im Zweiten Weltkrieg erreicht, in denen mehrere Millionen Menschen durch harte Zwangsarbeit oder gezielte Tötung ums Leben kamen.

 ------------ 

A part of the refugee camp has been preserved until today in transformed form and serves as a place of memory of events in the First World War, which have almost been forgotten. The spatial extent, in which the huge number of refugees and the evacuated were accommodated, becomes apparent, when we look at today's "Gartenstadt". And still this camp was only one amongst many others, which were to be found on the entire territory of the Austro-Hungarian monarchy.

Despite the fact that the refugee camp existed for a very short period of time (i.e. only two years), it had been part of a longer lasting historical development. Camps made of barracks for prisoners of war had already existed since the 19th century. About 1900 the first camps for civilian internees were designated as concentration camps, for example in the Spanish-American War in Cuba (1898) or in the so-called Second Boer War in South Africa (1899-1902).

The camps of all warring states in the First World War had huger dimensions and new forms of architecture. Especially the Austro-Hungarian monarchy built an extensive system of camps for prisoners of war, the "Feindstaatenausländer" (i.e. citizens from other states living in the Austro-Hungarian monarchy), the evacuated and the refugees, which were called "Sammelniederlassungen", "Barackenstädte", "Internierungsstationen" or "Konzentrationslager". They were used for the subsistence of the displaced, but also for the control and isolation of crowds.

A barbarous culmination of this development were the Nazi-extermination camps in the Second World War, in which millions of people were killed by severe forced labour and systematic and targeted killing.

 ------------ 
Most of the refugees were living in barracks. Apart from the barracks the camp comprised also 17 masoned family homes. The house on Pröllplatz 1 was constructed as one of the two four-family houses and is still preserved.

description.value:
Das Haus Schirnböckgasse 6-8 wurde ebenfalls als Zweifamilienhaus errichtet. Wie viele Flüchtlinge tatsächlich in einem Haus untergebracht wurden und wie diese Häuser innen ausgestattet waren, ist nicht bekannt. Vom Flüchtlingslager Gmünd wissen wir, dass in den gemauerten Häusern besser situierte Flüchtlinge wohnten als in den Baracken. Deshalb liegt die Vermutung nahe, dass dies auch hier in Hollabrunn der Fall war.

 ------------ 

The building in the Schirnböckgasse 6-8 was built as a semi-detached house as well. How many refugees were in fact accommodated in such a house and what its interior looked like, is unknown. From the refugee camp in Gmünd we have information that well-off refugees lived in masoned houses and not in barracks. Therefore, we may assume that the same was the case in Hollabrunn.

description.value:
Die heutige Schirnböckgasse mit ihren Familienhäusern stellte die Vorzeigestraße des Lagers dar. Im Vergleich zu den Holzbaracken handelte es sich hier um komfortablere Behausungen, die alle heute noch erhalten sind.

Es wurden drei Typen von Familienhäusern gefertigt, die sich lediglich durch ihre Himmelsausrichtung unterschieden. Das Haus Schirnböckgasse 3-5, entspricht dem sogenannten "gemauerten Zweifamilienhaus Type 10", das im Lager insgesamt fünfmal errichtet wurde. Ein erhaltener Plan zeigt uns die Raumaufteilung.
 ------------ 
Today's Schirnböckgasse with its family houses was a "show case" street of the camp. In comparison to the wooden barracks they were comfortable housing, which are still preserved.

Three types of family houses were built, which differ only in their orientation. The house in the Schirnböckgasse 3-5 is a type called "gemauertes Zweifamilienhaus Type 10", which was erected altogether five times in the camp. A preserved plan illustrates the room layout.

description.value:
Rechts der Übelbachergasse bis hinauf zum Wald befanden sich zahlreiche Baracken, die dichter als die gemauerten Gebäude zusammenstanden. Hier lebte die überwiegende Zahl der Flüchtlinge.

Sieben Baracken wurden mit festen Mauern errichtet. Dadurch waren sie haltbarer und wetterbeständiger und existieren teilweise heute noch. Die Baracke in der Übelbachergasse 37 wurde verkleinert und zum modernen Wohnhaus umgebaut.

 ------------ 

To the right of the Übelbachergasse up to the forest were to be found numerous barracks, which were more densely built than the masoned houses. It was here that most of the refugees were accommodated.

Seven barracks were built with massive walls. That is why they were more durable and weatherproof and, thus, partly exist until today. The barrack in the Übelbachergasse 37 was reduced in size and refurbished into a modern residential building.

description.value: Das gesamte Flüchtlingslager war von einem Holzzaun umschlossen. An dieser Stelle (Ecke Wienerstraße/Dr. Kutschergasse) befand sich das Haupttor. Das Betreten und Verlassen der Internierten und des Lagerpersonals konnte hier überwacht werden. Die Hollabrunner Bevölkerung durfte das Lager nicht betreten. ------------ The entire refugee camp was surrounded by a wooden fence. At this place (now on the corner Wienerstraße/Dr. Kutschergasse) was located the camp's main gate. It was here that the entering and leaving of the interned and the camp's personnel could be controlled. The inhabitants of Hollabrunn were not allowed to enter the camp.

description.value:
An dieser Stelle befand sich eine von über dreißig Wohnbaracken aus Holz, in denen die Mehrheit der Flüchtlinge Quartier bezog. Die Holzbaracken hielten der Nässe und Kälte nicht stand, sodass sie wenige Jahre nach dem Krieg wieder demoliert wurden.

Zur Zeit der stärksten Belegung waren im Lager Oberhollabrunn etwa 4000 Flüchtlinge untergebracht. In den großen Holzbaracken haben bis zu hundert Personen geschlafen. 

Die Bewohner*innen mehrerer Baracken teilten sich sogenannte "Küchenbaracken", die mit dem zur Verpflegung Notwendigsten ausgestattet waren.
------------
At this place was located one of thirty wooden barracks, in which the majority of the refugees lived. The wooden barracks did not withstand humidity and cold and, therefore, were demolished a few years after the war.

In the time of the strongest occupancy about 4,000 refugees lived in the camp Oberhollabrunn. In the huge wooden barracks up to 100 persons were sleeping. 

The inhabitants of several barracks shared so-called "kitchen barracks", in which the most necessary provisions were provided.

description.value:
Gemäß dem Plan des Flüchtlingslagers Oberhollabrunn sowie den Akten des Bundesministeriums für Handel und Gewerbe, Industrie und Bauten befand sich hier, am äußersten Rand des Lagers, in der heutigen Emmy Stradal Straße 12, die Leichenhalle mit Einsegnungskapelle.

Bis 1999 war die Kapelle laut Lokalhistoriker Walter Johann Fittner außen im Originalzustand erhalten. Danach wurde der Glockenturm abgerissen und das Gebäude umgebaut. Heute ist es ein privates Wohnhaus.

 ------------ 
According to the map of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn and the files of the Austrian Ministry of Trade and Commerce, Industry and Construction from the year 1922 a mortuary with a chapel was located at this place (now in the Emmy Stradal Straße 12). 

Based on information provided by the local historian Walter Johann Fittner, the outward appearance of the chapel had been preserved until 1999. Then, the belfry was pulled down, the building was converted and is now a single family house.

description.value:
Auf dieser Seite der heutigen Emmy Stradal Straße befanden sich vier Krankenbaracken, von denen eine als Wohnhaus erhalten ist (jetzt Emmy Stradal Straße 20).

Ein Spitalmagazin, eine Spitalküche und ein Ambulatorium waren an die Krankenbaracken angeschlossen.

Die schlechten Lebensbedingungen, die Mangelernährung und die Ausbreitung von Krankheiten führten zu zahlreichen Todesfällen unter den Flüchtlingen. In den Totenbeschaubefunden der orthodoxen Flüchtlinge wurden Lungentuberkulose und Herzparalyse als häufigste Todesursachen angegeben. Auch gastroenterologische Krankheiten, virale Infektionen und Unterernährung traten gehäuft auf.
------------
On this side of the Emmy Stradal Straße four barracks for the sick were to be found. One of them is preserved as a residential building (now Emmy Stradal Straße 20).

The hospital's storeroom, the hospital's kitchen and the outpatient clinic were attached to these barracks for the sick.

The bad living conditions, the malnutrition and the spreading of diseases led to a high death toll among the refugees. The coroner's records of deceased Orthodox refugees indicate that lung tuberculosis and heart paralysis were the most frequent causes of death. Gastroenterological diseases, viral infections and malnutrition were also very common.

properties.title: Oberhollabrunn, Flüchtlingslager, moderne römisch-katholische Kirche "Maria, Hilfe der Christen"

description.value:
Die römisch-katholische Kirche "Maria, Hilfe der Christen" wurde unter der Leitung des Pfarrers Karl Österreicher im Jahre 1970 errichtet. Gemäß dem Lagerplan standen an dieser Stelle Wohnbaracken für die Flüchtlinge.

Auch im Flüchtlingslager wurden Gottesdienste abgehalten. Für die orthodoxen Gläubigen gab es zwei Seelsorger, die selbst als Flüchtlinge interniert waren:
Der Geistliche Basil Arijczuk floh aus Toporoutz, Bukowina (heute Toporivtsi, Ukraine).
Pfarrer Kornel Pihuliak aus Babin, Bukowina (heute Ukraine), wohnte mit seiner Frau Augustine seit August 1916 im Lager. Der gemeinsame Sohn Roman kam hier im selben Jahr zur Welt.

Der ebenfalls internierte Pfarrer Bilinsky aus Galizien las Messen für die griechisch-katholischen (unierten) Flüchtlinge und spendete die heiligen Sakramente, wie uns in der Oberhollabrunner Pfarrchronik überliefert wurde. An welchem Ort dies geschah, ist unbekannt. Die ursprünglich geplante Kirche wurde nicht errichtet.

------------ 

The Roman Catholic Church "Maria, Hilfe der Christen" ("Mary, Aid of the Christians") was built under the direction of the parish priest Karl Österreicher in the year 1970. According to the map of the refugee camp residential barracks for refugees were standing in this area.

Divine services were also held in the camp. The Orthodox Christians had two ministers, who were themselves interned as refugees:
The cleric Basil Arijczuk had fled from Toporoutz in Bukovina (today Toporivtsi, Ukraine).
The priest Kornel Pihuliak from Babin in Bukovina (today in Ukraine) was living with his wife Augustine in the camp since August 1916. Their son Roman was born in the camp in the same year.

The interned priest Bilinsky from Galicia held divine services for the Greek Catholic refugees and administered the sacraments, which is documented by the parish chronicle of Oberhollabrunn. It is unknown, where this took place. The originally planned church was not erected.

description.value:
Aufgrund der großen Anzahl an Menschen, die während des Transportes und in den Lagern auf engstem Raum zusammengepfercht waren, breiteten sich zahlreiche Infektionskrankheiten aus. Im Eingangsbereich des Lagers wurden drei Quarantänebaracken errichtet.

An dieser Stelle (Dr. Kutschergasse 8) ist eine der Quarantänebaracken im Original erhalten. Sie ist im Frühling und Sommer wegen des natürlichen Bewuchses schwer zu erkennen.
------------ 
Because of the huge number of people, who were herded in cramped spaces during the transport to the camps and in the camps themselves, many infectious diseases were spreading. Therefore, three barracks for quarantine were built in the area close to the camp's entrance. 

At this place (now in the Dr. Kutschergasse 8) one of these barracks for quarantine is still preserved. In spring and in summer it is not easy to discern due to the vegetation.

description.value:
Das heute noch erhaltene Haus Emmy Stradal Straße 21 ist im Lagerplan als Restaurant eingezeichnet. Wie die Bewirtung ausgesehen hat, ist nicht überliefert. Die Lebensmittel sind allgemein im Verlauf des Krieges für die gesamte Bevölkerung knapper und teurer geworden. Die Flüchtlinge haben dies besonders zu spüren bekommen.

Der sozialdemokratische Abgeordnete Grigorovici, ein Rumäne aus der Bukowina, prangerte in einer Rede vor dem Reichsrat die schlechte Versorgung der Flüchtlinge in den Lagern an, wie die "Neue Freie Presse" am 13. Juli 1917 berichtete: 

"Es seien Flüchtlinge in Schnee und Frost stundenlang gegangen, um ein Stückchen Brot zu erlangen. Schon Gereinigten habe man wieder die alten Kleider gegeben. Besonders in Oberhollabrunn seien die Ernährungsverhältnisse geradezu unhaltbar. Man könne die Leute kaum vor den ärgsten Ausschreitungen zurückhalten."

 ------------ 
The still preserved house in the Emmy Stradal Straße 21 is marked as a restaurant on the map of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn. It is unknown, what kind of service was offered to the guests. Food had become scarcer and more expensive for the entire population in the wake of the war. The refugees were especially affected by this situation.

The Socialist deputy Grigorovici, a Romanian from the Bukovina, denounced the poor supply of the refugees in the camps in his speech in front of the Reichsrat. The newspaper "Neue Freie Presse" from 13 July 1917 reported: 

"The refugees were going for hours in snow and frost in order to receive a piece of bread. Already cleaned refugees got their old clothes back. Especially in Oberhollabrunn the state of nutrition was almost unbearable. It was nearly impossible to prevent the people from excessive rioting."

description.value:
Das noch erhaltene Schulgebäude des Flüchtlingslagers am Dr. Viktor Zeidler Platz 2 wurde im Sommer 1917 feierlich als Volksschule für Flüchtlingskinder eröffnet.

Neben dem Schulunterricht für Kinder wurden in den k.k. Flüchtlingslagern und Internierungsstationen auch Deutsch- und Alphabetisierungskurse sowie verschiedene Handarbeits-Werkstätten für Erwachsene angeboten. Diese kulturellen Angebote dienten sowohl der Beschäftigung der Insassen als auch der Stärkung ihrer patriotischen Gesinnung.

Im Oktober 1917 überreichte eine Delegation von Flüchtlingen aus der Bukowina der kaiserlichen Familie Handarbeiten, die hier im Lager hergestellt wurden.

------------ 

The still preserved school building of the refugee camp at Dr. Viktor Zeidler Platz 2 was solemnly inaugurated as primary school for the child refugees in the summer of 1917.

Apart from the teaching of children, adults attended courses of German and alphabetisation as well as of handicraft in Austro-Hungarian refugee camps and detention camps. These cultural activities served the purpose to keep the refugees occupied, but also to strengthen their patriotic attitude.

In October 1917 a delegation of refugees from the Bukovina presented items of handicraft to the imperial Habsburg family, which had been made in the camp Oberhollabrunn.

description.value:
Auf dem heutigen Pröllplatz 2 befand sich das Warenhaus des Lagers, das mittlerweile in einen Kindergarten umgebaut wurde.

Welche Lebensmittel im Flüchtlingslager an die Insassen verteilt wurden, ist nicht überliefert. Von anderen Lagern wissen wir aber, dass die Ernährung überwiegend aus Bohnen, Kraut, Polenta und Graupen (Tarhonya) bestand. Qualität und Menge der Nahrung nahmen im Laufe des Krieges ab.

In den regionalen Zeitungen wurde immer wieder von Lebensmitteldiebstählen durch Flüchtlinge, etwa auf den umliegenden Feldern, berichtet. Dies führte zu ihrer zunehmenden Ablehnung durch die ortsansässige Bevölkerung. 

Die "Wochen-Zeitung für das Viertel unter dem Manhartsberg" berichtete am 22. September 1916 über das Lager Oberhollabrunn: "Dank der Evakuierung von Teilen Ostgaliziens und der Bukowina sind schon mehr als 2000 Flüchtlinge in unserem Lager untergebracht. Leider gibt es darunter auch viele Notleidende, die es mit 'Mein' und 'Dein' nicht sehr genau nehmen. Namentlich Weintrauben und Erdäpfel erfreuen sich der besonderen Vorliebe und Aufmerksamkeit dieser Elemente."
------------ 
On Pröllplatz 2 was located the store of the camp, which has been converted in the meantime into a kindergarten.

It is unknown, what kind of food was distributed to the refugees in the camp. We do know that the nutrition in other camps consisted mainly of beans, cabbage, polenta and pearl barley. The quality and the quantity of the food diminished in the wake of the war.

The regional newspapers reported time and again on the theft of food on surrounding fields by the refugees. This led to a growing repudiation of the refugees by the local population. 

The newspaper "Wochen-Zeitung für das Viertel unter dem Manhartsberg" reports on 22 September 1916 on the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn: "Due to the evacuation of parts of Eastern Galicia and the Bukovina more than 2,000 refugees are already accommodated in our camp. Unfortunately, there are also many destituted among them, who are not caring very much for the fact that there is 'mine' and 'yours'. In particular, grapes and potatoes are especially cherished by these elements."

description.value: This palace was a gift to Prince Mihailo Obrenović by his father Prince Miloš Obrenović. The house was in possession of the Obrenović family from 1855, and after Prince Mihailo's divorce from Princess Julie in 1865, she received this house with an estimated value of 100,000 ducats. The building does not exist anymore.

Djordje Vojinović de Užički (1833-1895) was elected two times as member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Parliament in Vienna from 1870 to 1873 and from 1879 to 1891. He became a member of the Upper House ("Herrenhaus") in the Austrian Parliament in 1892. 

From 1901 to 1907 Andrija Vujatović Šarov (1841-1934) was a member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Austrian Parliament in Vienna.

After the renumeration it was Fleischmarkt 5, but this building was demolished at the beginning of the 20th century.

properties.title: Printing House of Joseph von Kurzböck

description.value: Josef Lorenz Ritter von Kurzböck (1736-1792) was one of the famous Viennese printers in the 18th century. On 31 January 1770 the Empress Maria Theresia (1717-1780) issued the "Privilegium impressorum", a privilege which granted to Kurzböck the right to open a printing house for Cyrillic publications. He became a privileged imperial Cyrillic printer for the next 20 years. Kurzböck did not not only have a monopoly for printing, but also on the import of these books. From March 1770 his proofreader was Sava Lazarević, the interpreter for the Serbian language at the Illyrian Court Deputation (Illyrische Hofdeputation). As censor in the printing house Ignjat Mihajlović, also chaplain of the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George in Vienna, was appointed on 14 December 1770. He held this position for about one year and was replaced by Atanasije Demetrović Sekereš, also a chaplain of the aforesaid Greek Orthodox Church of St. George. Demetrović converted to Cathoilcism in 1776, but still remained a censor for Cyrillic books untill 1794. Most of the books printed in Kurzböck's printing house were church books in Church Slavonic language. From 1770 to 1791 99 books, pamphlets, regulations and other publications were printed here. In 1792 Kurzböck sold his printing house together with its privileges and all books on stock to Stefan Novaković.

geometry.title: Joseph von Kurzböck printing house
geometry.description: Josef Lorenz Ritter von Kurzböck (1736- 1792) was one of the famous Viennese printers in the 18th century.  On 31 January 1770 Empress Maria Theresia issued the “Privilegium impressorium privatum”, a privilege which granted to Kurzböck the right to open a Cyrillic printing house. He became also a privileged imperial Cyrillic printer for the next 20 years. He had not only a monopoly on printing, but also on the import of these books. From March 1770 his proofreader was Sava Lazarević, the interpreter for the Serbian language at the “Illyrische Hofdeputation”.The censor was appointed on 14 December 1770 Ignjat Mihajlović, also the chaplain of the St. George Greek chapel in Vienna. He was on this position about one year and was replaced with Atanasije Demetrović Sekereš, also a chaplain of the St. George Greek chapel in Vienna. Demetrović converted to Cathoilcism in 1776, but still remained Censor for Cyrillic books untill 1794.  Most of the books printed in Kurzböck’s printing house were church books, in Church Slavonic language. From 1770 to 1791 99 books, pamphlets, regulations and other print formshere were printed. In 1792 Kurzböck sold his printing house together with the privileges and all books on stock to Stefan Novaković.

description.value: In the year 1792 Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) sold his printing house to Stefan von Novaković for 25,000 forints. Although Novaković was only owner for three years (from 1792 to 1795), his contribution to the history of Serbian publishing was enormous. Among other books, he printed one of the first Serbian history books of the historian and Archimandrite Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) in 1794/95 entitled "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"). In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house. Stefan von Novaković sold his printing house to Pest University in 1795. His printing house was in Salvatorgasse 456 (1010 Vienna), which was after renumeration house No. 6. The building does not exist anymore.

Allthough Novaković was only owner for three years, his contribution to Serbian publishing history was enormous. Among other books, in 1794/95 here was printed one of the first Serbian history books of the historian and archimandrite Jovan Rajić („Историји разних словенских народов, наиаче Болгаров, Хорватов и Сербов из тами забвенија изјатаја и во свет историческиј производеннаја“). Novaković sold his printing house to Pest University in 1795.  His printing house was in Salvatoregasse 456, after re-numeration it was house no. 6. The building does not exist anymore.

properties.title: Publishing House of the Mekhitarist Congregation

description.value:
The Mekhitarist Congregation is present in Vienna since the beginning of the 19th century. The Austrian Emperor Franz I (1768-1835) accepted the Mekhitarist monks in December 1810. Initially in 1811 the Mekhitarist fathers found shelter in the deserted buildings of the old Capucine convent "Am Platzl" in the suburb of St. Ulrich. In 1837 they started with the erection of new premises. The main wing of the new monastery followed the lines of the Mechitaristengasse (1070 Vienna). In 1874 two cross wings and a new church were added and so the monastery reached its present configuration. 
The Mekhitarist monks established a publishing house in 1811 and were active until 1873. From 1873 to 1876 the publishing house was in possession of Karl Seidl and Felix Mayer. This publishing house is of the greatest importance for the history of Serbian literacy and literature. It was the first publishing house in the world, which used Vuk Karadzić's (1787-1864) orthography (30 letters), and his "Riječnik" ("Dictionary", 1818) was printed as the first book in history with this new orthography. 
In the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation Djordje Natošević (1821-1887) published pedagogic books, for example spelling instructions for teachers in Vienna in 1858 ("Упутство за предавање букварски наука учитељима народних училишта у Аустријском царству").

geometry.title: Mechitaristen printing house
geometry.description: The Mechitaristen Congregation is active in Wien since the 1770s. They established a printing house in 1811 and were active until 1873. From the 1873 to 1876 printing house was in possession of Karl Seidl and Felix Mayer. This printing house is of greatest value for the history of Serbian literacy: it was the first printing house in the world with Vuk Karadzić’s orthography (30 letters) and his “Riječnik” (1818) was printed as the first book in history with this new orthography. The building still exists.

description.value:
The permanent settlement of Serbs in Vienna began in the course of the 17th century. The first settlers were merchants, who transported goods from the Ottoman to the Habsburg Empire and were thus granted freedom of trade by the Habsburg emperor Leopold I (1640-1705) in 1670.  A larger number of Serbs most probably reached Vienna in connection with the second Ottoman siege of 1683. The siege lasted from 14 July to 12 September 1683. Since the garrison was cut off from the Austrian and Polish relieving force, scouts were needed for the exchange of letters and messages between the separated bodies of troops. At least one of them was a merchant of Serbian origin, namely Georg Thomas Michaelowitz. After the Ottoman defeat the Serbs most probably founded their own area of settlement outside the city walls called "Ratzenstadel" (“Razen Stadtl”), which derives from the Hungarian word for Serb (“Rác”) and the German deductions "Raizen, Raitzen, Rascier", which again points to the Serbian medieval region of "Raška" (also known today as Novi Pazar, Serbia). The "Ratzenstadel" lay in the sixth district (1060) of Vienna, which is today "Mariahilf".
"Im Volksmund wurde die Vorstadt das (!) Ratzenstadel genannt. Der Begriff dürfte sich von den Serben oder Raizen ableiten, die dort ihre ersten Wohnstätten in Wien hatten." Cf. https://www.geschichtewiki.wien.gv.at/Magdalenengrund_(Vorstadt)

description.value:
Teodor von Bajić (1846-1897) died in the Sanatorium Löw on 26 March 1897 at the age of 50 and was buried on 28 March in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof) in 1110 Vienna. 

Bogdan Medaković (1854-1930), a Serbian politician and lawyer, died also in the Sanatorium Löw in Vienna on 11 May 1930.

Prince Mirko Petrović Njegoš (1879-1918) died in the Sanatorium Löw on 3 March 1918, where he was treated due to his illness since 1916. He was buried in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) on 14 March 1918 with all military honors.

Stanoje Stanojević (1874-1937), a Serbian historian, a Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade, died in the Viennese Sanatorium Löw on 30 July 1937.

description.value: Thaddäus Edler von Schmidbauer was active between 1791 until his death in 1825. In his printing house were printed "Novine Serbske" and other Serbian books. The address was since 1801 Bürgerspital 1100 and the bookstore was to be found at Graben "zur blauen Krone". The huge complex of buildings called Bürgerspital was demolished in the 1870s and 1880s. It was located between today's Maysedergasse, Neuer Markt, Kärntner Straße and Lobkowitzplatz. Schmidbauer's son Josef continued to work in the printing house after the father's death.

properties.title: Serbian Orthodox Church of Saint Sava in Veithgasse

description.value:
Around the middle of the 19th century the Viennese Serbs set about founding their church parish of Saint Sava under the leadership of Privy Councillor Dr. Georgije Stojaković (1811-1863). The Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I (1848-1916) permitted, at the request of the Serbian Patriarch in Sremski Karlovci Josif Rajačić (1785-1861), the constitution of the parish and the collection of donations. The constitutional meeting took place in November 1860. At this time, about 500 Serbs were living permanently and about 1,000 temporarily in Vienna. The Serbian parish received free of charge a site on the Franz-Josefs-Kai (1010 Vienna) for the erection of a new church, but the building could not start due to the lack of funds until the year 1890, which meant that a new site had to be looked for, since the old one had been already used in the meantime.
Until the year 1886 an amount of 80,000 florins (Gulden) had been collected. 80% were donated by Serbs, while 20% were given to the parish by other inhabitants of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, whose donations are recorded in the "Golden Book of the Serbian Orthodox parish in Vienna, Names of donors and benefactors" (Златна књига српске православне црквено-школске опћине у Бечу, Имена прилагача и добротвора). The total sum recorded in the Golden Book amounts to 25,210 florins (Gulden) and enabled the Serbian Orthodox parish to acquire a site in Veithgasse 3 (1030 Vienna) for 27,000 florins (Gulden) in 1889. The erection of the church began in 1890 under the supervision of the architect Heinrich Wagner, who himself donated 200 florins (Gulden). The erection of the building was completed in 1893 at an expense of 58,000 florins (Gulden), and the church has the capacity to hold 400 believers. 
After the constitution of the Serbian Orthodox parish, there existed along with the two Greek Orthodox parishes of Saint George and the Holy Trinity all together three Orthodox parishes in Vienna, and that is why it was necessary to determine a new domain of jurisdiction. After an agreement between the three parishes, the governorship of Lower Austria (Erzherzogtum Österreich unter der Enns) decided on 1 May 1893 that the new Serbian Orthodox parish had jurisdiction over all Orthodox people of Slavic nationality. 
On 19 November 1893 the church was consecrated to Saint Sava, the patron saint of all Serbs, in the presence of the Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I, an event that was reported in several Viennese newspapers. It marked the beginning of a very fruitful period of Serbian religious and cultural life in the Austro-Hungarian capital that lasted until the outbreak of the First World War in 1914.
The first priest of the parish was Mihajlo Mišić (1864-1924) from 1896 to 1924. He was followed by Bogdan Popović (1925-1927), Dr. Rodoljub Stojaković (1927-1935) and by Dr. Miloje Aranicki (1935-1941).
In 1904 the Serbian Ladies' Benevolent Society in Vienna ("Serbischer Frauen Wohltätigkeitsverein"). was founded and had its office in the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava (Veithgasse 3, 1030 Vienna). Its founder and president was Jelena Ostojić (1874-1967), the daughter of Aleksandar Ostojić (1839-1917).

description.value: The fourth Slavic Ball took place in the Sofiensäle on 27 January 1847. The music was performed by Johann Strauss Senior (1804-1849) and his orchestra. Its owner was Jovan Vladislav, a canvas merchant and one of the main initiators for the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna in 1860. On 9 December 1860 this Community was founded in his apartment, and Jovan Vladislav was its first Vice President. The original building does not exist anymore.

description.value:
Milutin Milanković studied civil engineering at the then College of Technology ("Technische Hochschule") in Vienna (now TU Vienna) and received his PhD there in 1904.
Here received Nikola Tesla, the famous Serbian inventor and scientist, his PhD honoris causa based on the decision of the council of professsors on 3 March 1908.

description.value: The first Slavic Ball took place in the Theater in der Josefstadt (Sträußelsäle) in Vienna on 4 February 1844. It (and also the subsequent Slavic Balls) was organised by students with the financial support of Princes Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) and Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868). Among the 300 guests was also Vuk  Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864).

properties.title: The House of the Family Bajić in Simmeringer Hauptstraße

description.value: This house was built by the Family Bajić in the 1840s. Already in the Cataster from 1869 the brothers Luka and Jovan von Bajić are mentioned as owners of the house in Simmeringer Hauptstraße 46 and Am Kanal 37 (it is the same object with entrances on both streets). The old Cataster number was Hauptstraße No. 277.

properties.title: Tomb of Jekatarina Obrenović in the St. Marx Cemetery

description.value: Jekatarina-Katica Obrenović (1826-1848), the daughter of Prince Miloš's youngest brother Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), died in Vienna on 25 July 1848 and, after a memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George, was buried in tomb No. 3 in the first row of the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 27 July 1848.

types.label: Burial Site

relations.label: Location of Tomb of Jekatarina Obrenović in the St. Marx Cemetery
relations.relationType: crm:P53 has former or current location

geometry.title: Tomb of Jekatarina Obrenović on St. Marx Cemetery
geometry.description: Tomb no. 3 in the first row at the Orthodox part of the cemetery. Here was buried the daughter of Jevrem Obrenović, Jekatarina- Katica Obrenović (1826-1848). She died in Vienna and after mass in the St George church (Griechengasse 8) was buried here on 15 January 1848.

properties.title: Tomb of Nikolić de Rudna family on St. Marx Cemetery

description.value: Tomb no. 4 in the first row at the Orthodox part of the cemetery. Here were buried Jelisaveta- Savka Nikolić de Rudna and her son Mladen before they were transferred to Rudna (nowedays Romania). Jelisaveta died in Vienna at the age of 35, and was buried here on 13 September 1848. In the same tomb was buried on 15 January 1849 her son Mladen, who died at the age of 5.

description.value:
In this building was located the Hungarian Court Office from 1747 to 1918. Today it is still the Embassy of Hungary.
Sava Popović Tekelija de Kevermes (1761-1842) was secretary at the Hungarian Court Office.

description.value: One of the most important Viennese concerts of Kornelije Stanković (1831-1865) was a charity concert of spiritual music in the Viennese Musikverein (then in Tuchlauben 12, 1010 Vienna) on 1 April 1861. The entire revenue was given for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna.

description.value:
The Votivkirche (Votive Church) is a neo-Gothic church in the city centre of Vienna. It was built following the attempted and failed assassination of Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) in 1853. The Emperor's brother Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian (1832-1867) inaugurated a campaign to create a church to thank God for saving the Emperor's life. Funds for the construction were collected throughout the Empire.
Isidor Nikolić von Serbograd (1805-1862), politician and writer, donated 10 ducats for the building of the Votivkirche in Vienna in 1853.

description.value:
The decision to establish a new, huge cemetery for Vienna was made in 1863, when it became evident that the city's population would increase to such an extent that the existing communal cemeteries would prove to be insufficient. The Viennese Central Cemetery was opened on All Saints' Day in 1874.
Vaso Djurdjević (1841-1915) died in Vienna on 26 December 1915 and was buried in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna). 
Svetozar Borojević von Bojna (1856-1920), an Austrian Field marshal of Serbian origin, died in Klagenfurt on 23 May 1920, where he was buried. Upon demand of the last Austrian Emperor Karl I (1887-1922) his mortal remains were transferred to a grave of honor in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) on 27 October 1920. Several thousand officers of the former Austro-Hungarian Army were present at this funeral.
